Now that the massuchusets Senator Scott Brown is elected he will be the 41st vote against the healthcare bill. With this, what ways can the bill still be implemented? Will the other Senators give in to more sweetheart deals? Will more Senators vote against it? Will this be enough or must we take it to the courts. Yesterday, Glenn Beck stated that the Democrats can get anything passed that they wanted with their supermajority. However, depending on what events take place from here to the mid-term elections can ultimately decide whether they willl keep it. Once more, if the republicans take power we can deal with the lessser of two evils but the real people we should be voting for are the independents. If the republicans win in November, then we should focus on getting the independents to be the ones in office. If we can succeed, then I doubt while they remain that anything like this monstrosity of a bill will ever be proposed again. But that is just my opinion.
 
 My real question is: Can the bill be stopped?emoticon_confused

 The possible scenarios that could get the healthcare bill made into law are both suicidal moves that will cause the Democrats to become Washington outsiders in quick order. They are:
 1. Get the HR to pass the Senate Bill without any changes. This will be suicidal to the most liberal Democrats and the most Conservative ones, because the Senate Bill is a neutered version of the House Bill.
 2. They drag their feet on certifying Brown until after the reconsiliation process occurs so that they maintain their supermajority. This option is ever worse than Option 1 because it exposes every Democrat in Congress for the unprincipled b@#$%rds that they are and will cause a firestorm against them for years to come.
